messageBody:
On 10/9/05, James Abley <james.abley@...> wrote:
>
>
> 1.2. Is this a bad question entirely? I.e. Am I in a state of sin for
> > wanting to switch around my unit tests from a command line?
>
>
> Possibly ;-), I've never felt the need to do it, but I've been lucky
> enough
> to avoid a ball of mud that big. I'm fairly sure there are other ways,
> Data-Driven Tests with a custom test suite might be a better option. I'm
> sure Cedric can suggest how TestNG provides for this.


Since you're asking :-)

Yes, being able to switch the set of tests quickly without recompiling
anything was one of the design goals of TestNG. Groups make this very easy.

For example, you can invoke TestNG like this:

java org.testng.TestNG -includegroups database

or

java org.testng.TestNG -includegroups web

Some of our users have more complex ways to select test methods, and
typically, they use

- Either different testng.xml files (testng-quick.xml, testng-nightly.xml,
etc...)

- Or BeanShell to select methods being run in more complex cases ("run group
'weekend' during the weekend and group 'weekly' during the week)

2. Is there a good way to test SWT?


Yes, Eclipse is automatically tested this way. A couple of Eclipse books
cover this and you can find more information on http://eclipse.org (I
realize you asked for SWT testing, but testing Eclipse is even more complex,
so testing SWT should be easier).


Google so far says 'not really'. I've made some painful conclusions and
> > design decisions from this. Chief among them has been, "if you need to
> > test the UI, you've probably got model code in your view classes. Fix
> > that first."


Sure, but you need to test the UI too. Just because your model works doesn't
mean that the UI does.

Cédric
